question: You think it's too early to call my mother?
answer: I don't know.

question: Hello, Ma, did I wake you up? This is Helen.... Well, I'll be going to work, and I wanted to get ahold of you before I left. I called you last night. Where were you and Pop anyway? I kept calling you every half hour up till one o'clock.... Oh, yeah? Did you have a nice time? ... Do you need any of this or can I take them off the table?
answer: I'll clean that up in a minute.

question: How late were you up last night?
answer: I'm taking five bucks from your drawer. A guy in my office is getting married, and I got clipped four bucks for his wedding present.

question: Who's getting married?
answer: Arnold. I told you about him. The guy with the sick mother.

question: Oh, yeah.
answer: The rest of the guys are giving him a bachelor party tonight.

question: Do you want to go, Charlie?
answer: I got class tonight.

question: What have you got -- cost accounting?
answer: Yes.

question: I think you ought to take off a night. You ought to go, have a little fun for yourself. I think you need that. You go to work all day, you go to school all night. You can miss one night, Charlie.
answer: No, these bachelor parties get kind of wild sometimes. The whole philosophy is

question: That's a good philosophy to start a marriage with.
answer: Well, a bunch of guys get together, they like to tear up the town a little.

question: I think you oughta go, Charlie. I know you're upset about the baby.
answer: I'm not upset about the baby.

question: Come on, Charlie. I know how you feel. Listen, you don't have to pretend you're excited about the baby. We weren't exactly planning on a baby right now ...
answer: I'm not upset about the baby.

question: It's a shock. I had some bad days before I told you. I said
answer: Well, give me a couple of days to get used to the idea. I'll be all right.

question: I know you will, Charlie. That's why I think you ought to go to this bachelor party tonight.
answer: I don't want to go to this bachelor party. I'm sorry I yelled.

question: Don't be silly.
answer: I better get going. Kenny's probably waiting for me now. I'm sorry I yelled like that.

question: You going to Arnold's bachelor party?
answer: I don't think so, Kennie.

question: What?
answer: I got two classes tonight.

question: Yeah, I was going to go, but I think I better not, because my kid, the young one, the girl, she's been acting up again lately. She's got some kind of allergy, the doctors don't know what.
answer: These bachelor parties get kind of wild sometimes. Eddie Watkins is making all the arrangements. He's probably got us lined up with a bunch of chorus girls.

question: Yeah, do you think so?
answer: You know Eddie.

question: Yeah, boy, he really lives it up, don't he? Did you see that blonde who picked him up for lunch last week? Boy, sometimes I wish I was a bachelor. Well, you know what I mean. I never seem to get out of the house any more, you know what I mean? About once a week, I go to the movies. We never even see the whole picture. My wife starts worrying about the kids. My youngest kid, the girl, she's got some kind of rash. We don't know what it is. I never seem to see anybody any more. Do you know how long it is since I've seen Willie Duff? I haven't seen Willie in about six months. My wife can't stand his wife. You ever seen her, Willie's wife?
answer: No, I didn't know Willie too well.

question: Boy, wait'll you have kids, boy. You'll never get out of the house.
answer: Helen's pregnant now.

question: No kidding.
answer: Yeah.

question: Oh, that's wonderful, Charlie, that's wonderful! Hey, there's a guy down there, trying to pick up a girl down there. Were you with us about eight years ago when I picked up that chick in front of the bus stop in Paterson, New Jersey?
answer: When was this?

question: Yeah, you were there. You were with that girl from Brooklyn. We just came from Palisades Amusement Park, and we were driving Frankie Klein's girl home, and the car broke down right in the middle of Route One.
answer: Oh, yeah.

question: And Frankie opened up the hood and the water cap blew right up in the air.
answer: And the cop came over ...

question: That's right, the cop. He thought Frankie shot off a gun.... He was going to pull us all in. Oh, man!
answer: Frankie, he was funny.

question: Oh, that was a lot of fun, those days.
answer: Yeah, they were.

question: Hey, this guy's making out all right. She's giving him the eye now. Where are we now, Prince Street? I bet you he picks her up before we hit Chambers Street.
answer: Boy, I'm bushed today. I was up till two o'clock last night on this thing here. I'm getting to be a nervous wreck. I snarled at Helen this morning. I think this whole night school business is getting me down.

question: I don't see how you do it.
answer: Neither do I. I thought I was through with it. The plan was for me to quit work and go to college full time and cram through in a year or so. But now we got this kid coming, and Helen's going to have to quit her job, and that sets me back where I started from. Another five years of this, summers included.

question: I couldn't do it, man, I'll tell you that. I wish I could, but I couldn't.
answer: Oh, what am I griping about? This is the life I picked out for myself. But it's a grind, boy, I tell you.

question: Hiya, Walter.
answer: Hiya, Walter.

question: Walter, what time do you come in in the mornings? You're making us all look lousy, you know that? I get the feeling sometimes, you stay here overnight.
answer: Arnold in yet?

question: He starts his vacation today. He's getting married Sunday, you know. Well, the doctor was over last night. Brought over the X rays; brought over the allergy tests. Brought over a bill for sixty-eight dollars. I said to him
answer: So what's wrong with you, Walter?

question: What's wrong? I have to go to Arizona, that's what's wrong. I have asthma. When I was a kid, they called it hay fever, and you carried a bag around your neck. Asafetida. Now, they call it asthma, and you have to go to Arizona. I said to him
answer: How serious is it, Walter?

question: Serious. Nothing serious. I have hay fever, I sneeze a couple of times. The idiot told my wife I have to go to Arizona, and she wouldn't leave me alone all night. She's already packing the bags. I said You better get to work. Hey, Charlie, that was the bell. I think Flaherty is here this morning. We'll all be fired today. I have a feeling. You fellows going to Arnold's party tonight?
answer: No, I'm not going, are you?

question: No. Eddie already hooked me for four bucks for Arnold's present. This dinner is going to cost another couple of good dollars.
answer: It looks like nobody's going to Arnold's bachelor party.

question: You ain't going?
answer: No, I'm not going.

question: Eddie's going to be mad.
answer: I told Eddie last week I couldn't make it. I've got school. Eddie's a bachelor. It's all right for him to go rooting around town, picking up girls.

question: I don't know where he gets all these girls. He's a screwy looking jerk.
answer: Did you see that blonde who was up here looking for him last week?

question: Yeah. He told me she was a television actress. I think I saw her once on "Studio One." She was in a coal mine with some stir-crazy coalminer who was trying to strangle her with a necktie.
answer: I'd like to strangle her with a necktie.

question: Now, Walter, an old married man like you, with asthma and everything.
answer: I get real jealous of Eddie sometimes. He's as free as a bird. Did you see that convertible he's got?

question: Yeah, he really banged it up I hear.
answer: You ought to see the old heap I've got. He walks out of here on payday, he can spend the whole works on having himself a good time. I walk out of here, and I got three kids and a wife, all of them with their palms out. I lost two bucks playing poker at my house last week. It was an economic catastrophe. My wife didn't sleep all night.

question: Mary, give me an outside line.... Hello, is this Leathercraft on Madison Avenue? ... This is Mr. Watkins. I was in about a week ago. I ordered a military set and a wallet. They were supposed to be ready yesterday.... Yes, please, would you? ... Yeah, a military set and a wallet....
answer: Is that what we bought poor Arnold?

question: That's right. The following inscriptions should be on them
answer: What's this, Jeanette?

question: I owe you, Eddie. I'll pay you tomorrow, payday.
answer: Miss Frances Kelley, please. I think it's room 417.... Hey, Evelyn, you owe me four bucks. Hello, Frances, this is Eddie.... All right, wait a minute. Give me a chance to explain.... I know I woke you up.... All right, let me tell you. You know I'm supposed to be the best man at this fellow Arnold's wedding. So I called him up last night because I didn't know whether I was supposed to wear tuxedo or tails. Well, he didn't know either, so he said What did I just tell that girl, Saturday night?

question: Yeah.
answer: Mary, give me Columbus 5-1098.... What do you mean personal calls! These are business calls! Well, stop listening to other people's conversations.... What have you got, stock in the company? Columbus

question: Listen, Eddie, I don't think I can go tonight. My father-in-law's in from Akron, Ohio, and----
answer: Hello, who is this, Mrs. Stebbins? ... This is Eddie, Mrs. Stebbins. I wonder if I can talk to Muriel.... Could I speak to her? ... Thank you.... Muriel, baby, listen, sweetie, I can't make it Saturday night.... I'm all loused up with this wedding I'm supposed to be the best man at.... We have to rehearse the ceremony. You'd think they were getting married on television.... Yes, sweetie, why don't I call you Monday. Maybe, we'll work out something before you go back to California.... All right, sweetie, good-bye. Well, what do you say? I'm going to call Louie and make a reservation for a table for tonight. Who's coming and who isn't? Walter, you're coming, right? It won't cost you more than three-fifty for the whole meal. What do you say, Walter? You only live once.

question: Hello, who is this, Mrs. Stebbins? ... This is Eddie, Mrs. Stebbins. I wonder if I can talk to Muriel.... Could I speak to her? ... Thank you.... Muriel, baby, listen, sweetie, I can't make it Saturday night.... I'm all loused up with this wedding I'm supposed to be the best man at.... We have to rehearse the ceremony. You'd think they were getting married on television.... Yes, sweetie, why don't I call you Monday. Maybe, we'll work out something before you go back to California.... All right, sweetie, good-bye. Well, what do you say? I'm going to call Louie and make a reservation for a table for tonight. Who's coming and who isn't? Walter, you're coming, right? It won't cost you more than three-fifty for the whole meal. What do you say, Walter? You only live once.
answer: That's right. You only live once.

question: Well, yes or no?
answer: All right, I'll come.

question: Hey, Charlie ...
answer: ... so we were stationed right outside Paris, about eight miles, a town called Chatou ...

question: ... hey, Charlie ...
answer: ... so the first night, a whole bunch of us swiped a jeep out of the motor court. We had a feller there who was a tech sergeant in the motor court. Oh, what a character he was! He used to get loaded every night on that vanilla extract.

question: It was sure nice of you fellows.
answer: Hey, man, we're having a ball!

question: De-Witt C-l-i-n-t-o-n Boom! Clinton! Oh, Cli-inton! Ever to theeeee! Fairest of high schools ...
answer: How did he ever get on this alma mater kick?

question: ... Give her three times three Oh, fellows ... Rah! Rah! Rah! Long may we cherish thee Faithful we'll be. Clinton, oh, Clinton For you and me ... Da-da-da-da-da ... Crash through that line of blue And send the backs around the end.
answer: There he goes with those fullbacks again.

question: You have a sense of humor, don't you?
answer: You're going great, man, don't stop now. Where are you going, honey? What's going on in there, honey?

question: There's a party going on. I'm not sure I'm invited myself, so I can't really invite you.
answer: Sure you can.

question: I haven't the vaguest idea. I was ambushed crossing Greenwich Avenue by a tribe of the Terre Haute Kiwanis.
answer: I always thought you city people were more hospitable to us poor farm boys.

question: He'll be back! Man, she likes you, man! Well, what do you say, men, are we going to this party, or aren't we?
answer: Come on, Eddie. I thought you had some movies you want to show us.

question: What do you want to see movies for? You got the real thing right here.
answer: Eddie, we're married men here.

question: Come on, let's crash this party. I've been to these Greenwich Village parties. Man, they're wild.
answer: Come on, Eddie, let's go up to your place, see these movies.

question: Man, you were going strong with that girl. You could have scored. She's just waiting for you. Go in after her.
answer: Come on, Eddie. Let's go see the movies.

question: Hiya, Julie. I was beginning to think you weren't coming.
answer: I was at my mother's house. Did they call you? They said they were going to call you.

question: Yeah, your mother was very sweet.
answer: You should have seen my father. I said, "Pa, you have another grandchild coming." So he said, "Who?" So I said, "Charlie." So he said, "That little Helen?" So I said, "If it isn't that little Helen, Charlie better leave town." So out came the beer. Well, they've been after Charlie to have a baby for a long time now. I said, "Pa, leave him alone. Let him get established before he saddles himself with a baby." Anyway, I want you to know joy reigns supreme in your in-laws' house. How's Charlie taking it?

question: Listen, let me make you a cup of tea or something.
answer: No, no, I've been drinking beer for the last two hours, celebrating your baby.

question: Soda, anything like that?
answer: No, honey, you go on with your wash. Is that what you're doing? When I had my first baby, Mike was ashamed to be seen on the streets with me. Well, listen, he was interning at the time. We needed a baby like a hole in the head. That's why he's a general practitioner now, because of that baby. He was studying to be a surgeon. He absolutely refused to admit I was pregnant. Even in my ninth month, and I was as big as a house. He used to walk ten paces in front of me in the street like he didn't know who that woman with the belly was. Where is Charlie anyway?

question: I told you he--
answer: Oh, yeah. I wouldn't let my Mike go on a bachelor party.

question: What are they going to do, get a little drunk?
answer: Are you kidding? What do you think these bachelor parties are for, bachelors? This is for the married men. It's a good excuse to get drunk and find some girls.

question: Can you picture Charlie getting drunk and picking up a girl? Charlie's old sobersides. You should have seen what I went through to get him to make a pass at me. He's so sweet. Nobody knows how really sweet he is, he's so quiet all the time. My brother died in September, he used to stay up with me till three, four o'clock every night. I used to cry all night, and he used to sit on the bed and talk with me. I used to look at him talking there, and I used to think
answer: Wait'll you've been married eleven years.

question: You like to talk about all the affairs everybody's husband is having. Do you know actually one woman whose husband is actually playing around?
answer: Wait'll you've been married eleven years. Wait'll Charlie gets to be forty-two. My Mike's having an affair right now with one of his patients right now. We don't talk about it -- don't you, either, not even to Charlie. But Mike knows I know about it. I even know the patient. A married woman with a hyperthyroid problem. My Mike's a good doctor with a pretty good practice. The kids are crazy about him. But every now and then he has to go out and get involved with a woman. Listen, I will take a cup of tea if you've got one.

question: You're kidding, aren't you?
answer: Would I kid about something like that? I don't know why I told you. Don't tell anybody, not even Charlie. I don't want the family to know. But this woman isn't the first one. I know that much. About three years ago, the doorbell rings. I open the door. There's a man there. He says We should have waited till he finished his internship. What kind of married life is that? Twenty-two dollars a month he was earning. Every other day, he had to sleep in the hospital. The first two years of our marriage, we didn't even see each other. And then I'm pregnant. He had to quit, what do you think? He wanted to be a surgeon, he wound up being a G.P. From that day he hated me. I had two other children by him, but he hated me. He told me in just so many words. Why do you think I kept telling you, Helen, why do you think I kept telling you

question: Are you all right, Julie?
answer: I'm all right. I'm all right.

question: ... He's a boy, my Mike. Till the day he dies, he'll never be more than fifteen. Perpetual adolescence, that's the curse of the professional man. He spends his whole youth trying to be a doctor, a lawyer, an accountant. Then he spends the rest of his life looking for the fun he should have had when he was a boy.
answer: Oh, I know. Charlie and I hardly even see each other.

question: It's very hard on the wife, Helen. These are the years when you should be building your marriage. Instead, you grow away from each other. I've seen it happen with my friends. In the end, they have nice homes in New Rochelle, and a maid, and their maids are happier than they are. But sometimes it does work. It can be done, Helen. Encourage Charlie to stay with his school because...
answer: Oh, I will, Julie ...

question: ... he's an ambitious boy ...
answer: ... oh, it's not just he's ambitious ...

question: ... and if he doesn't fulfill himself, he'll resent you and your baby the rest of his life.
answer: Oh, I don't want him to quit. He loves accounting, Julie. I see him sometimes, sitting over his homework. He's got his ledgers out, and he's adding up columns of figures as long as his arm. And he's chuckling. You'd think he was reading the comics. He has a book there, Business Law. How he can read it I don't know. But I'll be watching television or something, and he'll come over, and he'll start telling me about some fine legal point. I don't know what he's talking about, but it's enough for me to see how excited it makes him. He loves it, Julie. You can't take something like that away from him. It's just -- it's just I feel we're not really close any more. I mean, he comes home from school, lots of times I'm asleep already. And, when I do see him, he seems all involved with himself. He looks at me sometimes as if I were a stranger to him, and I feel sometimes I am. I'm afraid of that, Julie.

question: Then get rid of the baby. If I had it to do again, believe me, that's what I would do.
answer: You don't mean that, Julie.

question: Yes, I do. My children are the only things in my life now, but I would rather have a husband.
answer: I wouldn't even think about it.

question: That's what I said, too.
answer: Let's not even think about it. If I even mentioned it, he'd -- he'd hit me, I think.

question: All right.
answer: I want this baby, Julie. I've wanted this baby for a long time. It's the only thing I've ever asked of Charlie. If I mentioned that to him -- I don't know what he'd do. Hello.... Hello, Charlie, where are you calling from? ... You sound like you're having a nice time.... Oh, you're having a ball, huh? ... Well, what time do you think you'll be coming home?

question: The party breaking up?
answer: I don't know. I'm going home. You going home?

question: Yeah, I think so. You love your wife, Kennie? I don't feel like going home. Are you going? Hang around, Kennie. It's only about nine thirty, ten.
answer: It's after ten. It's about ten after ten. The party's getting a little wild in there anyway. Eddie and Walter got poor Arnold nailed in there, they're trying to talk him into getting a girl. This party's going to wind up in a joint, let me tell you. This is a good time to blow.

question: Yeah.... I should have gone to class tonight. I'm paying twenty bucks a credit. The least I can do is go to class. I take one night off, I can't even enjoy myself. Did you know Eddie went back to Europe?
answer: No, I didn't know that.

question: He was telling me he lived in Paris for three months. I'd like to do that!
answer: What's the matter?

question: I'm going to quit. What am I killing myself for?
answer: Quit what?

question: Quit night school. Tonight was the first laughs I've had in years. I can't remember the last time I had so much fun. Look what I'm missing. I'm making a pretty good living. I can support a wife and baby on what I make. I'm going to quit! I mean it. I'm going to quit. Boy, what a time to have a baby.
answer: You don't have to quit school because you're having a baby, Charlie. There are lots of guys go to night school with two, three kids.

question: You ought to meet some of these guys. They're just grinding their lives away. It's an obsession with some of these guys. I mean, what's the point? So I'll go five more years to night school. So I'll get my degree. So I'll get a job as a junior accountant for three years at seventy-five bucks a week. I'm making better than that now. And then it just starts. The CPA exams. By the time I'm fifty, I can start living. At this point, I get a heart attack and an ulcer, and they bury me in the ground, and they say
answer: Come on, let's go home.

question: What do I want to go home for?
answer: You're in a lousy mood. Charlie, go home. I can see you're going to get fried tonight and wind up picking up a tramp and you're going to wake up in the morning feeling like two-bits.

question: It'd be a profit.
answer: Charlie, about five years ago, I went without a job for seven months. Alice was carrying our first baby. We were living on money I borrowed from my brother. I don't know if you remember me in those days, but it was rough. I used to go out every night, put a load on, and make a pass at any girl who looked at me. And I mean any. Big, tall, short, fat, anything. Well, one night I picked up some tomato somewheres, and we were sitting in a bar or somewheres, and I kept calling her Alice all night. So she says to me

question: What does that mean?
answer: I don't know. I had a point when I started telling that story.

question: I'm not looking for another woman.
answer: Yes, you are, Charlie. You may not know it, but you are. So go on home, Charlie, before you get any drunker than you are. Charlie, you start messing with other women, something goes. It'll kill your marriage. It'll kill your wife. It'll just kill her. What my wife went through -- well, I don't even want to remember it. It's never the same with your wife again, Charlie.

question: I'm not looking for any woman.
answer: I think what I was trying to say was you stick with your night school. Some guys have to make peace with themselves that they're never going to amount to too much. A guy like me. Once I made that peace with myself, I found out it doesn't really matter what you amount to. I got a nice wife and two children I complain about all the time, but if anything ever happened to either one of them, I think I'd die. But you don't have to make that kind of peace, and you'd be crazy to settle for less than what you want. You want something, Charlie. I think that's wonderful. You're a little drunk now, and you're fed up to the teeth. Everybody gets fed up, Charlie. You stick with it. You're going to be all right.

question: You're a nice guy, Kennie.
answer: Sure. You're a nice guy too.

question: Wait a minute.... What are you, a wise guy?
answer: Come on, Charlie, let's go home.

question: Listen, Charlie, I'd like to ask you a little advice. I mean, you're a married man. This girl, I'm supposed to marry, she's all right, but I'm not really attracted to her, you know what I mean? That's important, isn't it? I kissed her a couple of times, but I ... I don't know why I'm getting married, Charlie.
answer: What did you say, Arnold?

question: I said, I don't know why I'm getting married. I did pretty good for thirty-two years without getting married. I get along fine at home. My mother's a good cook. I have a nice life. What do I want to break it all up for?
answer: Well, Arnold, everybody feels that way before they get married.

question: Yeah? Did I ever show you a picture of my girl?
answer: No, you didn't, Arnold.

question: Do you want to see a picture?
answer: Sure.

question: I want you to give me your honest impression, Charlie. She isn't much, is she?
answer: I can't see much in this light, but she looks like a nice pretty girl.

question: Well, I wouldn't say that. We were matched up, you know. The families kind of agreed on it. I was brought over to her by my mother and father. That's how I met her. She's some kind of tenth cousin. She's all right. She's quiet. I kissed her a couple of times. She just sat there and I kissed her. I think she expected more. She even asked me that. She said to me
answer: What do you mean, Arnold?

question: I mean, you think I ought to marry her?
answer: Well, Arnold, even if I knew the girl, I wouldn't answer that question. I may not like her, but she may be fine for you.

question: Because I'm thinking of calling the whole thing off.
answer: It's kind of late for that, isn't it?

question: I'm scared stiff, Charlie.
answer: What are you scared about?

question: I'm not much of a talker, and she's one of those quiet ones. What are you supposed to do with your wife? I mean, most of the time.
answer: Most of the time, Arnold, you don't even see her. You're away working. You come home, she fixes you supper. Then one of you washes the dishes. Then if you're not tired, you can go to the movies or visit somebody. Or you watch teevee.

question: I do that now with my mother.
answer: I don't know what there is to marriage. I suppose it's to have kids.

question: So what do you think I ought to do? You think I ought to go through with this marriage?
answer: Arnold, I can't answer that!

question: I'll wait out here for you, okay?
answer: Listen, I don't want you to think I don't have a job. I got a job. I work. What's the matter? Are you afraid of me? What's the matter? Hey. Hey, you. Hey, you, what's the matter?

question: Let's go. What's the trouble?
answer: I don't know. Ask him. What's the matter? Hey, you. You, what's the matter?

question: Go back inside.... All right, all right.
answer: How about that, huh?

question: What happened, Arnold?
answer: I don't know. I'm just scared.

question: Yeah, I don't blame you, I'd be scared too like this. I don't know why we dragged you up here in the first place. It's a barbaric custom. Come on.
answer: Don't tell Eddie.

question: No I won't, Arnold.
answer: Why don't we just sit here for ten minutes or so?

question: All right, Arnold.
answer: Don't ever tell anybody.

question: It's nothing to be ashamed of.
answer: Please, Charlie.

question: What are we, all out? So let's go to this party then. Hey, Charlie, come on.
answer: Cut it out.

question: You can have that girl you picked up on Tenth Street. Come on.... All right, you married men want to be so married that's all right with me. But I'd like to see some women tonight. Come on.
answer: Lay off.

question: I'd like to see some women tonight, you know. Do you mind?
answer: Cut it out, Eddie. You keep punching me, I swear I'm going to belt you one.

question: You mess around with other women, it kills your wife and it kills your marriage.
answer: All right, you guys go home, and I'll go on my merry way. Hey, you guys, you guys want to go to a nutty night club, look at the nuts? There's a nutty night club over on Second Avenue. You know what we can do? Charlie, you live in Stuyvesant Town, don't you?

question: Yeah.
answer: You know what we can do? We'll take the crosstown. We'll go over to Charlie's house, he'll get some money, and we'll go to this nutty night club. It's right down on Second Avenue. You got any money home, Charlie?

question: What do you say, Arnold? You want to go?
answer: Charlie, get Walter.

question: Come on, Walter....
answer: I'm going to die, you know what I mean? Excuse me ... excuse me ... So what'll I do? I mean, he says, I'm going to die. I mean, the man's a specialist. He says

question: Walter, why don't you just quit the job and pack your bags and get out of here?
answer: I can't quit. Don't you understand? You don't understand. I can't quit! I got a fourteen-year-old girl, I don't know what time she comes in at night any more. She's so wild, these kids. I got a nineteen-year-old boy in college; he's going to be a doctor if I have to die. He's not going to quit school. You hear me! I worked hard to put that kid in school! I don't care if I die! I don't care! What am I going to do in Arizona? Who wants me? Who's going to give me a job? What kind of a job am I going to get? I'm forty-eight years old. They don't want no forty-eight-year-old bookkeeper. They got machines from IBM. You ever been up on the ninth floor? You ever see all those IBM machines? What am I going to do out in Arizona? You look in the Help Wanted lately? You see any jobs listed for Bookkeeper, Male? What are you talking about? Do you know what you're talking about?

question: Easy, Walter.
answer: Take your hand off me. You don't know nothing! You're just a kid! You don't know! I've seen death, kid. I've seen it, boy. I know what it looks like. Excuse me.... Forty-eight years old and so what? What does it mean? What happened? What have I got? What did I make? Who needs me? So this is it. A man's life, nothing. Worry about being sick, worry about making money, worry about your wife, worry about your kids, and you're on your way to the grave from the day you're born. The days drag on, and the years fly by, and so what? What is it all about? Will you tell me? Life is nothing! It's a gag! It's a joke! It's a mortgage! It's a bankrupt! It's a lot of noise over nothing! Sound and fury! Isn't that what the man said? What do you think, I never read a book? I read a book! Don't worry! I was a bright kid! Everybody thought I was going to be the first Catholic to be President! Where did it all go?! Where did it all go?

question: Yeah.
answer: I'm going home.

question: What did you say, Walter?
answer: I'm going home.

question: That's me in fifteen years. That's where I live.
answer: Which one?

question: In the back there. You can't see it from here.
answer: It looks like a state hospital.

question: It looks like a prison.
answer: Yeah, it does look a little like a prison.

question: I'm going home.
answer: Hey, Charlie ... Hey, Charlie! What about the money? Have you got ten bucks?

question: All right, if you want to walk me to the house, I'll get you ten bucks. I'll be right out.
answer: Hiya, have a nice time?

question: I'm taking ten bucks. A couple of the guys are waiting outside. I promised them I'd loan them ten bucks.
answer: Sure.

question: Tomorrow's payday. I'll get it back tomorrow.
answer: It's in the drawer. What's the matter, Charlie?

question: I don't know.
answer: It's not so bad, Charlie.

question: I know. I know. I don't know what's the matter with me, I keep getting so depressed. I'm going to quit night school, Helen. My nerves are shot. Those guys are waiting outside. I better give them their money.
answer: Charlie ... Maybe I shouldn't have the baby?

question: What do you mean? ... Isn't that dangerous? ... Well, I don't know ... maybe ... Well, you brought it up.
answer: You really don't want this baby.... You're my husband, Charlie. This is your baby too. That doesn't mean anything to you. For the first time in our marriage I feel I can't depend on you, Charlie -- I'm not important to you. I could make my life sound hard, too, Charlie. I work all day, I rush home, I make you dinner. I sit home alone four nights a week, I'm even alone when you're here because when do I see you? But it was easy for me because I loved you. Do you think I care whether you're an accountant or a ditch digger, or even out of work? All I ever wanted was you. And this baby because it's you, too. Leave me alone, Charlie.

question: I decided I'd quit school and ...
answer: I don't care ...

question: I decided I'd quit school and come home in the evenings like everybody else and live a normal life.
answer: I don't care what you do, Charlie.

question: I don't care what I do either.
answer: What took you so long? What did you do, blow open the safe?

question: Here.
answer: I'll give it to you tomorrow. I'll see you in the morning, Charlie.

question: I'll see you. Wait a minute. I'll go with you.
answer: Let's go to that party -- we'll have a ball!

question: Let's go to that party -- we'll have a ball!
answer: I'm sure that's the police again. Are you coming to complain about the noise?

question: Do we look like complainers?
answer: I don't know who you are, but come in, come in. I don't know half the people who are here tonight. The police have been here twice. The first fellow was just adorable. We gave him a drink, and he's upstairs in a bedroom now, for all I know.

question: Is that right?
answer: If you want something to drink, you'll just have to go into the kitchen and get it yourself. The place is just mad. Do you write, paint or sing?

question: Everything.
answer: Boy, do you get invited to a party like this or do you get committed?

question: Beat it. This is going to be like shooting ducks. Pick out your duck, men. Hey, what's the matter, Charlie?
answer: Let's get out of here, Eddie.

question: The last time I saw you, you was with that girl you picked up. What happened?
answer: She's over there talking to that old guy with the glasses. I didn't like her. She's one of these real Greenwich Village phonies. If I added up all the guys she told me about, she must have had her first boy friend when she was two years old. Where are you going, Eddie. Stick around a minute.

question: I'm with that one over there -- not bad, huh? I think she's a Communist. I think she's trying to talk me into joining the Party.
answer: How are you making out?

question: Not so hot. I may have to join.
answer: Hang around. Let's talk a bit.

question: I better get back. She's liable to recruit somebody else.
answer: Where's Arnold?

question: He's in the kitchen. I think he's out cold. I'll see you.
answer: Hey Arnold-- You okay, Arnold?

question: Hey Arnold-- You okay, Arnold?
answer: That old man I was talking to before? That's my landlord. About ten thirty last night, someone began pounding on my door. So I got up and opened the door, and there was this white-haired man with a pince-nez standing there. I said

question: You have an apartment around here somewheres? What's up there? What kind of rooms are up there?
answer: So, I finally got to sleep around six thirty....

question: Come on, let's go.
answer: No! Oh, stop trying to be so primitive. I find you very unpleasant. There's nothing upstairs. Oh, I don't care. So I finally got to sleep around six thirty this morning. At nine thirty, someone began pounding on my door again. I got out of bed and opened the door, and there was my landlord with the pince-nez wearing a blue silk kimono. "Oh, for heaven's sakes," I said, "what do you want now?" He said Just say you love me.

question: What?
answer: Just say you love me. You don't have to mean it. No, don't. ...

question: What's the matter?
answer: Say you love me....

question: Come on.
answer: Say you love me....

question: Come on....
answer: No ...

question: I love you! I love you!
answer: Look, maybe we ought to go someplace else? I'm having a very tricky thing going with my landlord and I don't want him to see us leaving together. So you know what you do? There's a bar down the street. You go out the door and turn to your right. You know the one I mean?

question: Yes, I know.
answer: Well, you go there and I'll be there as fast as I can. Now, wait for me now, because I can't stand being alone at night. You'll like me. I'm supposed to be very amusing. All right?

question: Hey, Eddie ... Eddie, I'm cutting out.
answer: Wait a minute, I'll go with you.

question: I don't want to take you away from your girl, Eddie.
answer: Aah, this one lives out in Long Island with her mother. What kind of Communist is that? It'll take me a half hour on the subway there and a half hour back.

question: Where's Arnold? Still in the kitchen?
answer: I guess so. I'll see you, next time I get to Long Island. Hey, Arnold, come on. Well, it wasn't a bad party. We killed a couple of hours anyway. ... I mean, you can't compare the two. This kid the Yankees have in centerfield. Are you trying to tell me he's a natural .368 hitter? What's he normally hit, .310, .315? Musial led the National League in hitting six times. He's only having a fair year, this year -- and he's still hitting .320. Musial is an all-time great!

question: ... Well, I mean, is there any argument? Hodges is the best first baseman in both leagues....
answer: So, Eddie, what do you think? You think I ought to marry her, go to China, or what?

question: Arnold, if it bothers you so much, call her up and tell her to forget the whole deal. All right Hodges is having a bad year -- but how about last year? He hit over .300. He only hit thirty- five homers and he drove in over a hundred runs----
answer: So, Eddie...

question: Arnold! Get rid of her! You're driving me crazy! All right, who's on second? We got Charlie Neal or Gilliam, for that matter, and this isn't even counting Jackie Robinson, head and shoulders, even with a trick knee, the best second baseman in both leagues if they'd let him play there. We got three guys, for Pete's sake, who can outplay anybody the Yankees put on second. Ever see Charlie Neal go to his right? That Yankee guy, what's his name -- he can't go to his right. And don't forget Neal gets a lot of bases on balls, and once he's on the bases, man, it unnerves the pitcher ...
answer: What's Brooklyn going to do for pitching?

question: Never heard of Newcombe? Never heard of Erskine?
answer: What have you got to compare with Ford, Kucks, McDermott, Turley---

question: McDermott -- McDermott hasn't pitched a full game since last year.
answer: The best relief pitcher in both leagues.

question: What's the matter with Eddie Roebuck?
answer: How do you compare Eddie Roebuck with McDermott?

question: What are you, a Yankee fan?
answer: Yeah.

question: Well, drop dead. A Yankee fan.
answer: I did it.

question: You did what?
answer: I just woke her up! I called her! I said

question: What a bachelor party. We start out celebrating the guy's wedding; we wind up breaking his engagement. What do we owe you here? Eddie, pay it, will you? I gave you the ten bucks.
answer: What do you want to go home for?

question: It's going to take us an hour to get him home. He lives in Queens somewheres. By the time I get back to Fourteenth Street, it'll be daybreak. What are you going to do, stay up all night? Don't you want to go home sometimes?
answer: What am I going to do home? I read all the papers.

question: Well, go to sleep then.
answer: Ah, don't go home, Charlie. I feel like doing something.

question: What? Stand around this bar and argue about the Yankees and the Dodgers? Wind up with some miserable, lonely girl who begs you to say, "I love you"? Go home, Eddie. Go to bed. You got to go home sometimes. I'll take Arnold home. Come on, Arnold, kid. I'm going to take you home.
answer: Hey, honey, what are you, a Yankee fan or a Dodger fan?

question: Well, thanks a lot, Charlie.
answer: You all right?

question: Yeah, I'm all right. I'm a little groggy, but I'm awake anyway. You don't want to come in, do you?
answer: No, I don't think so.

question: I think my father and mother are up. I hear voices. My girl must have called them because they wouldn't be up at this hour.
answer: Well, you just go in and explain to them that you were drunk, and you're sorry, and you'll call your girl the first thing in the morning because she must really be upset about this.

question: I think she's here.
answer: Who?

question: My girl. I think I hear her voice in there.
answer: Well, be nice to her, Arnold. Remember, you woke her up in the middle of the night and probably scared her to death.

question: What'll I say to her, Charlie?
answer: I don't know, Arnold. What do you feel like saying to her? Do you really love this girl? Do you want to marry her? Are you marrying this girl because your family wants you to marry her, or why?

question: I think I like her, Charlie. It's just that I'm afraid I won't make a good husband.
answer: Well, tell her what you told me, Arnold. Tell her you're scared, and that you don't think you'll make a good husband. If she's a halfway decent girl, she'll try to understand how you feel, and, if she loves you, she's going to make it her job to make you happy. That's what love is, Arnold, when you have somebody else in the world you want to be happy. My wife, Arnold, I don't know what I'd do without her. Arnold, I've got a tough grind ahead of me. Work all day, I'll go to night school at night. But my wife knows that I need this to be happy, and she does everything she knows to help me. And we've got a baby coming. But if you love that baby and you love your wife, then it's easy. Everything seems so easy to me now -- I don't know why I even thought of quitting. Arnold, I want my wife so much right now. I want her to be happy. I want to just go home and hold her and tell her how much she means to me. I mean, even Walter, he's going to die, but don't you think he'll be in tomorrow morning, same old Walter, jokes and laughs? He's got somebody to live for. He's even got somebody to die for. I mean, how rich can a man be? And poor Eddie -- I used to be so jealous of him. I used to think he was so free. Free from what? From loving a woman, from really wanting a woman. Arnold, what I'm trying to tell you is life is nothing if you don't love somebody but life is wonderful if you do love somebody. Arnold, I want my wife so much right now ...

question: I'm going to tell her about that woman tonight and everything. I'll tell her about that woman.
answer: Arnold, I want to get home so much to my wife right now I'm going to bust.

question: I'll see you, Charlie.
answer: Good-bye, Arnold, have a nice honeymoon. I'll see you when you get back.

question: I'll see you, Charlie. Hello, Louise. I'm very sorry, honest.
answer: I love you, Helen.
